newsitem.title: USA: Regular showers seen in U.S. Midwest next week.
newsitem.headline: Regular showers seen in U.S. Midwest next week.

text.p: A parade of storms producing light to moderate rain should move across the U.S. Midwest next week, even across the dry areas of central Illinois, central Indiana and southwest Ohio, meteorologists said.
"Just about every day there will be rain somewhere in the Midwest next week," said Tim Bowden, Weather Express Inc meteorologist.
He said the week's rain amounts should range from 0.50 to 1.50 inches with 70 to 80 percent coverage.

The storms begin late Friday in the western Midwest and move east during the weekend. Another rain system was forecast Monday and Tuesday in the west and then slowly move into eastern Midwest areas Wednesday and Thursday, said Joel Burgio, Weather Services Corp agricultural meteorologist.
"The most important region would be central Illinois, central Indiana and southwest Ohio, which has been trending drier," said Burgio, who expects rain there.
High temperatures next week should reach the low 80s degrees Fahrenheit in the southern Midwest and 70s in the north, which would average below normal.
He noted that forecasts suggest this may be the first year this century that Chicago does not have an 80-degree day in May.
He said the best chance for 80s in Chicago are Saturday and Sunday after that the area turns cooler for the balance of the month.
